Award.AwardTitle: The Two-Body Problem: An Evaluation of University Partner Accommodation Policies with Implications for Recruitment, Retention, and Promotion of STEM Women

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite decades of various efforts meant to increase the number of women in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) disciplines, women in these fields remain under-represented on university faculties. Female faculty in STEM disciplines are more likely than their male counterparts to be partnered with another academic and more likely than men to refuse a job offer if their partners cannot find adequate employment at the same location. In light of such facts, and in an effort to increase the proportion of female faculty in STEM fields, many universities have adopted partner-accommodation policies (PAPs). Until now the prevalence and type of PAPs in U.S. universities and the efficacy of PAPs to recruit productive faculty as well as recruit and retain women STEM faculty has been unknown. This research provides a much needed description of PAPs in U.S. universities, as well as both theoretical and empirical evaluations of PAPs and their implications for the recruitment, retention, and promotion of women in STEM disciplines. The current state of PAPs will be documented and the relationship between PAPs and the gender diversity in STEM fields will be estimated. A rigorous modeling approach enriched with insights from sociology and economics will be developed and tested
with faculty productivity, retention, and promotion data via the collaboration of an information
technology expert who specializes in coordinated academic data collection and analysis. The theoretical model predicts that in any institution other than the most selective, a faculty member who is hired as part of a dual hire couple is likely to be more productive than an individual hire. Preliminary findings at Washington State University (WSU) support the hypothesis that, on average, faculty hired via a PAP program are more productive in terms of publications and grants, less likely to leave the university, and more likely to obtain tenure and promotion than faculty hired outside of formal PAP programs. In addition to WSU, data has been obtained from University of Wyoming. Agreements to acquire data have been made with Virginia Tech and Southern Connecticut State University, with additional requests at four other universities. Data
will also be collected via the internet and randomly selected follow-up phone interviews to assess the existence and type of PAPs and sex composition of STEM fields at 270 institutions. A web-based survey of tenure-line faculty will be administered as part of this proposed project. The survey will focus on faculty?s non-academic life (e.g., parental status, age of children in the home, marital status and timing), race/ethnic background, job search strategies, career and job satisfaction, anticipated mobility, long-term commitment to the university and their experiences, if any, being part of an academic dual-career couple and use of university PAPs. Increasing the representation of women in STEM faculties is a general societal objective. Understanding the impact of PAPs is one potential approach to finding effective ways to increase the number and the success of women on university faculties in technical disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vision of this project was to understand how prevalence and type of partner-accommodation policies (PAPs) in U.S. universities and effectiveness in recruiting and retaining productive women in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) disciplines. Using theoretical models, university administrative data, productivity data, we evaluated whether there is a productivity difference across faculty depending on whether they were hired via a PAP or in the traditional way.  The overall answer is that faculty hired via a PAP are at least as productive if not more productive than traditional hires.

Using our faculty survey data, we find that department-level partner accommodation stigma (PAS) is negatively associated with institutional satisfaction and commitment. Further analyses of the survey data have revealed an element of risk-taking in the job search process. Specifically, the decision to reveal dual-career status in the academic job search process impacts faculty members’ later promotions, productivity, pay, mobility, and career-related goal setting. Members of a dual-career couple who took the most risk (i.e., revealed their dual-career status before a job offer) later reported significantly more positive career experiences than those who did not reveal their status in the job search stage. Because of the nature of academic hiring, revealing a risky status during the job search process may ameliorate barriers to employment. Furthermore, we found that among dual-career academics recruited to the university first, women are more likely than men to have considered refusing a job offer and leaving had their partner not found suitable employment. These findings hold net academics’ ranking of the importance of their career relative to that of their partner’s and highlight the potential for dual-career hiring policies to help gender diversify the academy.  We have communicated these results across a broadly variety of outlets and forums.

The new knowledge and information are documented in a series of publications, dissertations, and conference presentations.  Dissemination of the information through these means provides the academic communities with new insights for recruiting and retaining STEM women who are part of dual career couples.  This project also provided a great opportunity for training a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students. The project information was also reached a more general population through media coverage, presentations, and popular articles. 

This project contributed to the ADVANCE program goals in terms of societal, economic, and education /workforce development imperatives.  This project results have produced multiple impacts: The research results have already been used and cited in the literature.  The graduate students trained are now active in various research and development positions in both university and private sectors. The project results have demonstrated the possibilities and challenges in hiring dual-career academic couples in STEM. The project has fostered collaborations among the members of the research team. The project results will continue to benefit the society by providing basic knowledge for developing policies and supporting women in STEM.
